trans-unit.source: How to manage service configurations and profiles
trans-unit.target: How to manage service configurations and profiles

trans-unit.source: Learn how to work with service configurations and profiles configuration files| which store settings for the deployment environments and publish settings for cloud services.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to work with service configurations and profiles configuration files| which store settings for the deployment environments and publish settings for cloud services.

trans-unit.source: How to manage service configurations and profiles
trans-unit.target: How to manage service configurations and profiles

trans-unit.source: Overview
trans-unit.target: Overview

trans-unit.source: When you publish a cloud service, Visual Studio stores configuration information in two kinds of configuration files: service configurations and profiles.
trans-unit.target: When you publish a cloud service, Visual Studio stores configuration information in two kinds of configuration files: service configurations and profiles.

trans-unit.source: Service configurations (.cscfg files) store settings for the deployment environments for an Azure cloud service.
trans-unit.target: Service configurations (.cscfg files) store settings for the deployment environments for an Azure cloud service.

trans-unit.source: Azure uses these configuration files when it manages your cloud services.
trans-unit.target: Azure uses these configuration files when it manages your cloud services.

trans-unit.source: On the other hand, profiles (.azurePubxml files) store publish settings for cloud services.
trans-unit.target: On the other hand, profiles (.azurePubxml files) store publish settings for cloud services.

trans-unit.source: These settings are a record of what you choose when you use the publish wizard, and are used locally by Visual Studio.
trans-unit.target: These settings are a record of what you choose when you use the publish wizard, and are used locally by Visual Studio.

trans-unit.source: This topic explains how to work with both types of configuration files.
trans-unit.target: This topic explains how to work with both types of configuration files.

trans-unit.source: Service Configurations
trans-unit.target: Service Configurations

trans-unit.source: You can create multiple service configurations to use for each of your deployment environments.
trans-unit.target: You can create multiple service configurations to use for each of your deployment environments.

trans-unit.source: For example, you might create a service configuration for the local environment that you use to run and test an Azure application and another service configuration for your production environment.
trans-unit.target: For example, you might create a service configuration for the local environment that you use to run and test an Azure application and another service configuration for your production environment.

trans-unit.source: You can add, delete, rename, and modify these service configurations based on your requirements.
trans-unit.target: You can add, delete, rename, and modify these service configurations based on your requirements.

trans-unit.source: You can manage these service configurations from Visual Studio, as shown in the following illustration.
trans-unit.target: You can manage these service configurations from Visual Studio, as shown in the following illustration.

trans-unit.source: Manage Service Configurations
trans-unit.target: Manage Service Configurations

trans-unit.source: You can also open the **Manage Configurations** dialog box from the role’s property pages.
trans-unit.target: You can also open the **Manage Configurations** dialog box from the role’s property pages.

trans-unit.source: To open the properties for a role in your Azure project, open the shortcut menu for that role, and then choose **Properties**.
trans-unit.target: To open the properties for a role in your Azure project, open the shortcut menu for that role, and then choose **Properties**.

trans-unit.source: On the **Settings** tab, expand the **Service Configuration** list, and then click **Manage** to open the **Manage Configurations** dialog box.
trans-unit.target: On the **Settings** tab, expand the **Service Configuration** list, and then click **Manage** to open the **Manage Configurations** dialog box.

trans-unit.source: To add a service configuration
trans-unit.target: To add a service configuration

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer open the shortcut menu for the Azure project and then click **Manage Configurations**.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer open the shortcut menu for the Azure project and then click **Manage Configurations**.

trans-unit.source: The **Manage Service Configurations** dialog box appears.
trans-unit.target: The **Manage Service Configurations** dialog box appears.

trans-unit.source: To add a service configuration, you must create a copy of an existing configuration.
trans-unit.target: To add a service configuration, you must create a copy of an existing configuration.

trans-unit.source: To do this, choose the configuration that you want to copy from the Name list and then click **Create copy**.
trans-unit.target: To do this, choose the configuration that you want to copy from the Name list and then click **Create copy**.

trans-unit.source: (Optional) To give the service configuration a different name, choose the new service configuration from the Name list and then click **Rename**.
trans-unit.target: (Optional) To give the service configuration a different name, choose the new service configuration from the Name list and then click **Rename**.

trans-unit.source: In the **Name** text box, type the name that you want to use for this service configuration and then click **OK**.
trans-unit.target: In the **Name** text box, type the name that you want to use for this service configuration and then click **OK**.

trans-unit.source: A new service configuration file that is named ServiceConfiguration.
trans-unit.target: A new service configuration file that is named ServiceConfiguration.

trans-unit.source: .cscfg is added to the Azure project in Solution Explorer.
trans-unit.target: .cscfg is added to the Azure project in Solution Explorer.

trans-unit.source: To delete a service configuration
trans-unit.target: To delete a service configuration

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, open the shortcut menu for the Azure project and then click **Manage Configurations**.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, open the shortcut menu for the Azure project and then click **Manage Configurations**.

trans-unit.source: The **Manage Service Configurations** dialog box appears.
trans-unit.target: The **Manage Service Configurations** dialog box appears.

trans-unit.source: To delete a service configuration, choose the configuration that you want to delete from the **Name** list and then click **Remove**.
trans-unit.target: To delete a service configuration, choose the configuration that you want to delete from the **Name** list and then click **Remove**.

trans-unit.source: A dialog box appears to verify that you want to delete this configuration.
trans-unit.target: A dialog box appears to verify that you want to delete this configuration.

trans-unit.source: Click **Delete**.
trans-unit.target: Click **Delete**.

trans-unit.source: The service configuration file is removed from the Azure project in Solution Explorer.
trans-unit.target: The service configuration file is removed from the Azure project in Solution Explorer.

trans-unit.source: To rename a service configuration
trans-unit.target: To rename a service configuration

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, open the shortcut menu for the Azure project and then click **Manage Configurations**.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, open the shortcut menu for the Azure project and then click **Manage Configurations**.

trans-unit.source: The **Manage Service Configurations** dialog box appears.
trans-unit.target: The **Manage Service Configurations** dialog box appears.

trans-unit.source: To rename a service configuration, choose the new service configuration from the **Name** list and then click **Rename**.
trans-unit.target: To rename a service configuration, choose the new service configuration from the **Name** list and then click **Rename**.

trans-unit.source: In the **Name** text box, type the name that you want to use for this service configuration and then click **OK**.
trans-unit.target: In the **Name** text box, type the name that you want to use for this service configuration and then click **OK**.

trans-unit.source: The name of the service configuration file is changed in the Azure project in Solution Explorer.
trans-unit.target: The name of the service configuration file is changed in the Azure project in Solution Explorer.

trans-unit.source: To change a service configuration
trans-unit.target: To change a service configuration

trans-unit.source: If you want to change a service configuration, open the shortcut menu for the specific role you want to change in the Azure project and then click Properties.
trans-unit.target: If you want to change a service configuration, open the shortcut menu for the specific role you want to change in the Azure project and then click Properties.

trans-unit.source: See [How to: Configure the Roles for an Azure Cloud Service with Visual Studio](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/hh369931.aspx) for more information.
trans-unit.target: See [How to: Configure the Roles for an Azure Cloud Service with Visual Studio](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/hh369931.aspx) for more information.

trans-unit.source: Make different setting combinations by using profiles
trans-unit.target: Make different setting combinations by using profiles

trans-unit.source: By using a profile, you can automatically fill in the **Publish Wizard** with different combinations of settings for different purposes.
trans-unit.target: By using a profile, you can automatically fill in the **Publish Wizard** with different combinations of settings for different purposes.

trans-unit.source: For example, you can have one profile for debugging and another for release builds.
trans-unit.target: For example, you can have one profile for debugging and another for release builds.

trans-unit.source: In that case, your **Debug** profile would have **IntelliTrace** enabled and the **Debug** configuration selected, and your **Release** profile would have **IntelliTrace** disabled and the **Release** configuration selected.
trans-unit.target: In that case, your **Debug** profile would have **IntelliTrace** enabled and the **Debug** configuration selected, and your **Release** profile would have **IntelliTrace** disabled and the **Release** configuration selected.

trans-unit.source: You could also use different profiles to deploy a service using a different storage account.
trans-unit.target: You could also use different profiles to deploy a service using a different storage account.

trans-unit.source: When you run the wizard for the first time, a default profile is created.
trans-unit.target: When you run the wizard for the first time, a default profile is created.

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio stores the profile in a file that has an .azurePubXml extension, which is added to your Azure project under the **Profiles** folder.
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio stores the profile in a file that has an .azurePubXml extension, which is added to your Azure project under the **Profiles** folder.

trans-unit.source: If you manually specify different choices when you run the wizard later, the file automatically updates.
trans-unit.target: If you manually specify different choices when you run the wizard later, the file automatically updates.

trans-unit.source: Before you run the following procedure, you should have already published your cloud service at least once.
trans-unit.target: Before you run the following procedure, you should have already published your cloud service at least once.

trans-unit.source: To add a profile
trans-unit.target: To add a profile

trans-unit.source: Open the shortcut menu for your Azure project, and then click **Publish**.
trans-unit.target: Open the shortcut menu for your Azure project, and then click **Publish**.

trans-unit.source: Next to the **Target profile** list, click the **Save Profile** button, as the following illustration shows.
trans-unit.target: Next to the **Target profile** list, click the **Save Profile** button, as the following illustration shows.

trans-unit.source: This creates a profile for you.
trans-unit.target: This creates a profile for you.

trans-unit.source: Create an new profile
trans-unit.target: Create an new profile

trans-unit.source: After the profile is created, click **<Manage…>** in the **Target profile** list.
trans-unit.target: After the profile is created, click **<Manage…>** in the **Target profile** list.

trans-unit.source: The **Manage Profiles** dialog box appears, as the following illustration shows.
trans-unit.target: The **Manage Profiles** dialog box appears, as the following illustration shows.

trans-unit.source: Manage Profiles Dialog
trans-unit.target: Manage Profiles Dialog

trans-unit.source: In the **Name** list, choose a profile, and then click **Create Copy**.
trans-unit.target: In the **Name** list, choose a profile, and then click **Create Copy**.

trans-unit.source: Choose the **Close** button.
trans-unit.target: Choose the **Close** button.

trans-unit.source: The new profile appears in the Target profile list.
trans-unit.target: The new profile appears in the Target profile list.

trans-unit.source: In the **Target profile** list, click the profile that you just created.
trans-unit.target: In the **Target profile** list, click the profile that you just created.

trans-unit.source: The Publish Wizard settings are filled in with the choices from the profile you selected.
trans-unit.target: The Publish Wizard settings are filled in with the choices from the profile you selected.

trans-unit.source: Click the **Previous** and **Next** buttons to display each page of the Publish Wizard, and then customize the settings for this profile.
trans-unit.target: Click the **Previous** and **Next** buttons to display each page of the Publish Wizard, and then customize the settings for this profile.

trans-unit.source: See [Publish Azure Application Wizard](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkID=623085) for information.
trans-unit.target: See [Publish Azure Application Wizard](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkID=623085) for information.

trans-unit.source: After you finish customizing the settings, click **Next** to go back to the Settings page.
trans-unit.target: After you finish customizing the settings, click **Next** to go back to the Settings page.

trans-unit.source: The profile is saved when you publish the service by using these settings or if you click **Save** next to the list of profiles.
trans-unit.target: The profile is saved when you publish the service by using these settings or if you click **Save** next to the list of profiles.

trans-unit.source: To rename or delete a profile
trans-unit.target: To rename or delete a profile

trans-unit.source: Open the shortcut menu for your Azure project, and then click **Publish**.
trans-unit.target: Open the shortcut menu for your Azure project, and then click **Publish**.

trans-unit.source: In the **Target profile** list, click **Manage**.
trans-unit.target: In the **Target profile** list, click **Manage**.

trans-unit.source: In the **Manage Profiles** dialog box, click the profile that you want to delete, and then click **Remove**.
trans-unit.target: In the **Manage Profiles** dialog box, click the profile that you want to delete, and then click **Remove**.

trans-unit.source: In the confirmation dialog box that appears, click **OK**.
trans-unit.target: In the confirmation dialog box that appears, click **OK**.

trans-unit.source: Click **Close**.
trans-unit.target: Click **Close**.

trans-unit.source: To change a profile
trans-unit.target: To change a profile

trans-unit.source: Open the shortcut menu for your Azure project, and then click **Publish**.
trans-unit.target: Open the shortcut menu for your Azure project, and then click **Publish**.

trans-unit.source: In the **Target profile** list, click the profile that you want to change.
trans-unit.target: In the **Target profile** list, click the profile that you want to change.

trans-unit.source: Click the **Previous** and **Next** buttons to display each page of the Publish Wizard, and then change the settings you want.
trans-unit.target: Click the **Previous** and **Next** buttons to display each page of the Publish Wizard, and then change the settings you want.

trans-unit.source: See [Publish Azure Application Wizard](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkID=623085) for information.
trans-unit.target: See [Publish Azure Application Wizard](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkID=623085) for information.

trans-unit.source: After you finish changing the settings, click **Next** to go back to the **Settings** page.
trans-unit.target: After you finish changing the settings, click **Next** to go back to the **Settings** page.

trans-unit.source: (Optional) Click **Publish** to publish the cloud service using the new settings.
trans-unit.target: (Optional) Click **Publish** to publish the cloud service using the new settings.

trans-unit.source: If you don’t want to publish your cloud service at this time, and you close the Publish Wizard, Visual Studio asks you if you want to save the changes to the profile.
trans-unit.target: If you don’t want to publish your cloud service at this time, and you close the Publish Wizard, Visual Studio asks you if you want to save the changes to the profile.

trans-unit.source: Next steps
trans-unit.target: Next steps

trans-unit.source: To learn about configuring other parts of your Azure project from Visual Studio, see [Configuring an Azure Project](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkID=623075)
trans-unit.target: To learn about configuring other parts of your Azure project from Visual Studio, see [Configuring an Azure Project](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkID=623075)

trans-unit.source: test
trans-unit.target: test
